msDesc.head: A: Paradisus animae intelligentis; Germany (Central Hessian region), s. xiv2/4-mid; B: Various texts, mainly on contemplation; Germany (Mainz Charterhouse), s. xiv2/4-mid (part B)

physDesc.p: This description is abbreviated from Daniela Mairhofer, Medieval Manuscripts from the Mainz Charterhouse in the Bodleian Library, Oxford: A Descriptive Catalogue (Oxford, 2018), pp. 1245–1257. For purposes of scholarly citation, reference to the printed catalogue is requested.

binding.p: Brown tanned calf over laminated pulpboard for Abp. Laud, 1637–1639.

history.provenance: MS. Laud Misc. 479 consists of two German parts: A) a German sermon collection, and B) a collection of Latin texts mainly on contemplation and the ascent to God; both were once in the possession of the Mainz Charterhouse, but were presumably brought together only in the course of the Laudian binding.
William Laud, 1573–1645: his ex libris, 1638, fol. 1r.
history.acquisition: Given to the Bodleian as part of his third donation, dispatched on 28 June 1639.

recordHist.source: See above. Previously described in the Quarto Catalogue (H. O. Coxe, Laudian Manuscripts, Quarto Catalogues II, repr. with corrections, 1969, from the original ed. of 1858–1885). msItem.title: Paradisus animae intelligentis
msItem.note: (sermon collection including 32 sermons of Meister Eckhart and another 32 sermons by preachers of his circle)
The writing language of the present manuscript can be located in the Central Hessian region, east of Mainz including the area of Frankfurt and the Wetterau (N. F. Palmer, 'In kaffin in got', 107ff.).

layoutDesc.layout: Ruling in ink, (fols. 1ra–4vb, index) two columns, (fols. 5r–113av) one column, of 32 lines. Ruled space c. 140–49 89–99

decoDesc.decoNote: Simple two- to four-line initials in red.

history.provenance: Mainz, Charterhouse St Michael: the 15th-century ex-libris inscriptions (lower margin of fol. 64r, in the same hand as the German ex-libris inscription in MS. Laud Misc. 521, fol. 138v; in a different hand, at the upper margin of fol. 113v).

msItem.author: Thomas Gallus (Ps.-Bonaventure)
msItem.title: De septem gradibus contemplationis
msItem.note: Shortened adaptation. See also Mainz, Stadtbibl., Hs I 48, fols 91r–v & 244ra–va.

msItem.title: De contemplatione
msItem.note: See also Mainz, Stadtbibl., Hs I 48, fols 91v–92v & 244va–245rb.

msItem.author: Bernard of Clairvaux
msItem.title: De consideratione
msItem.note: Excerpts from 2.2.5–14.31.
See also MS. Basel, UB, B IX 6, fol. 1ra–va; Mainz, Stadtbibl., Hs I 48, fol. 92v.

msItem.title: Octo gradus quibus viri contemplatim ascendunt
msItem.note: Excerpt from William of Saint-Thierry (Ps.-Bernard of Clairvaux), Epistula ad fratres de Monte Dei, 44.
See MS. Basel, UB, B IX 6, fol. 8ra–va; Mainz, Stadtbibl., Hs I 48, fol. 94r (end).

msItem.title: Quod duodecim sunt quae praeparant ad contemplationem
msItem.note: The text breaks off at the sixth article.
See also Mainz, Stadtbibl., Hs I 48, fols 94r–102v & 147r–155v (complete).

msItem.title: Septem gradus animae
msItem.note: A tractate based on Augustine, De quantitate animae, 33.

msItem.title: De tribus speciebus visionis
msItem.incipit: Et distinguuntur ibi in glosa tres species visionis corporalis ymaginaria et intellectualis
msItem.note: Cf. MS. Basel, UB, B IX 6, fol. 8va.

msItem.title: De gloria animae et corporis et gaudiis caelestibus
msItem.incipit: Sciendum est de rebus sperandis quod gloria anime. et gloria corporis sunt speranda
msItem.note: At the end of the first gaudium (fol. 125r) a ‘Frater wydo cartusiensis’ is quoted as authority, making a Carthusian source/origin very likely.

msItem.author: Gérard of Liège (Ps.-Hugh of Saint-Cher)
msItem.title: De doctrina cordis
msItem.note: Excerpts from the seven tractates, in an unusual order.

At the beginning a short preface, apparently composed by the scribe at the Mainz Charterhouse, where he states that the tractate De scissione cordis was put at the beginning of the work for reasons of convenience, while in the copy of dominus Fulzo ad Gradus (the Mainz canon Fulzo de Longa Curia), it is preceded by several other tractates.
See also Mainz, Stadtbibl., Hs I 48, fols 102v–147r.

msItem.author: Richard of Saint-Victor
msItem.title: Beniamin maior
msItem.note: Excerpts from 1.4–5.19.
See also MS. Basel, UB, B IX 6, fols 1va–7va; Mainz, Stadtbibl., Hs I 48, fols 147r–155v.

msItem.author: Richard of Saint-Victor
msItem.title: De quatuor gradibus violentae caritatis
msItem.note: See also MS. Basel, UB, B IX 6, fols 78r–87v; Mainz, Stadtbibl., Hs I 48, fols 234r–242r.

msItem.author: Gregory the Great
msItem.title: Homiliae in Ezechielem
msItem.note: Excerpts from 1.10.43 & 2.3.8–9.
See MS. Basel, UB, B IX 6, fols 87v–88r; Mainz, Stadtbibl., Hs I 48, fol. 242r–v.

msItem.title: Sermo de BMV
msItem.note: See MS. Basel, UB, B IX 6, fols 87v–88r; Mainz, Stadtbibl., Hs I 48, fols 88r–90v.

msItem.author: Gérard of Liège (Ps.-Hugh of Saint-Cher)
msItem.title: De doctrina cordis
msItem.note: See above, item 12. Excerpt, ascribed to Albert the Great.

supportDesc.support: parchment and Italian paper (two watermarks: Briquet 15852 (Genoa 1334–1336) and the other similar to Briquet 3165 (Bologna 1329, Pisa 1330/1331, Montpellier 1336) (see Palmer, 'In kaffin in got', pp. 109–110)

layoutDesc.layout: Ruling (fols. 114r–123v) in lead point, hardly visible; the paper quires without ruling; (fols. 124r–141v, 196r–199v) in ink, the ruling pattern varies, as does the number of lines. Ruled space c. 143–50 98–102

handDesc.handNote: German textualis, presumably a single hand, from the Mainz Charterhouse.

decoDesc.decoNote: A six-line initial in red, filled with fleuronnée in the ink of the text (fol. 114r).
Simple two- to five-line initials, mostly in red.

history.provenance: The evidence of script and watermarks suggests that part B was copied at the Mainz Charterhouse, s. xiv2/4–mid.

Mainz, Charterhouse St Michael: a 15th-century ex-libris inscription (fol. 114r); fascicle B is identifiable in the older catalogue of 1470 (Mainz, Stadtbibl., Hs I 577, fol. 273r) as ‘VII. S (= secundus)’ and as ‘M. VII. P’ (= primus) in the younger catalogue compiled before 1520 (Mainz, Stadtbibl., Hs I 576, fol. 167r)
